The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: I Need not ≈øpend much time in giving you an account how the≈øe en≈øuing Sermons come to be made publick. It is not becau≈øe. I de≈øire to bee in print; But it is

1 To pre≈øent you with the Pattern of a Woman whom God did pick out to make an example of great affliction, and great patience, that when you come into great troubles, you may bee comforted with tho≈øe comforts, with which ≈øhee was comforted.

It is the grand ≈øin of mo≈øt people to delay and prorogue their ≈øolemn preparation for affliction and ≈øickne≈øs, till they come to bee ≈øick, and in affliction. To prevent your delaying and deferring,
to provide for affliction, the≈øe Sermons are printed, and to per≈øwade you, that what≈øoever you do for Heaven, you would do it ≈øpeedily, and with all your ≈øtrength.

The Subjects handled are ≈øo plain and ea≈øy, and the ≈øtile ≈øo rude and unpoli≈øhed, that I was re≈øolved to ‚Ä¢ ave buried them in perpetual oblivion, had I not been conquered by this following (together with the forementioned) con≈øideration, that they are calculated only for people under great troubles, at which times learned debates about Di≈øcipline, and controverted points of Divinity, painted Eloquence, and curious Language, are of very little e≈øteem, and account. Afflicted con≈øciences are oftentimes puzzled, but never comforted with doubtful di≈øputations. Neat and elegant expre≈ø≈øions may skin over, but cannot cure ≈øpiritual di≈øea≈øes. Nothing can heal a wounded con≈øcience, and keep a man from ≈øinking into di≈øpondency in the day of great tribulation,
but a real, right, and particular Application of the Promi≈øes, to help a doubting Chri≈øtian to perform this great work, there are thirteen plain Rules and Directions laid down in the following Treati≈øe. My prayer is, that they may prove u≈øeful and ≈øucce≈ø≈øeful.

Seneca indeed comforts his friend Polybius, and per≈øwades him to bear his afflictions patiently, becau≈øe hee was the Emperours Favourite, and tells him, That it was not lawful for him to complain, while Cae≈øar was his Fas tibi non e≈øt de fortuna conqueri ≈øalvo Cae≈øare. friend: But this was but a poor Cordial: For Cae≈øar him≈øelf a little while after, was ≈øo mi≈øerable, that hee had not a friend to help him, much le≈ø≈øe was hee able to help his friend. My purpo≈øe at fir≈øt was only to have printed the Sermon preached at Mris. Moores Funeral, together with her Evidences for Heaven, collected by her in the time of her health. div.p: 16 Take heed le≈øt being led away with the errour of the wicked, you 2 Pet. 3. 17 fall from your own ≈øtedfa≈øtne≈øs. Take heed of a threefold Apo≈øtacy, of which this Nation is deeply guilty.

17 Remember that it is the will of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, that you who partake of the ≈øame word of life, and of the ≈øame Sacramental Bread and Wine, ≈øhould admoni≈øh one another, exhort one another, watch over one another, bear the burdens of one another, provoke one another to love and good works; ≈øeek the good of one another, and not

Gal. 6. 1‚ñ™ Rom. 15. 2. Rom. 14. 7. 2 Cor. 5.15‚ñ™ 1 The≈ø. 5. 11, 13, 14. The≈øe Texts will ri≈øe up in Judgement again≈øt thou≈øands of Chri≈øtians at the la≈øt day. I do not ≈øay that you are to admoni≈øh none but tho≈øe of your own Society. Admonition is an act of mercy; It is ≈øpiritualis Eleemo≈øyna, ≈øpiritual Almes, and you are bound by the royal law of charity, by the communion of Saints, the communion of Churches, and communion of natures, to di≈øtribute the≈øe ≈øpiritual almes to all that need them, as God ≈øhall give occa≈øion. That you may the better di≈øcharge this duty, you mu≈øt labour to bee acquainted one with another, as far as your callings and relations will give you leave. It is a great and common ≈øin, and much to bee lamented, That there is ≈øo little knowledge and acquaintance,

They ≈øit in the ≈øame Pew together, partake of the ≈øame Sacrament, and yet conver≈øe no more together, than if one lived at York, and the other at London. And when they do conver≈øe together; it is a meer civill and outward conver≈øe, as among≈øt ≈øober heathens; But there is very little religious ≈øociety between them, for the ≈øpiritual edification one of another. And yet 'tis not my opinion that every member of a Congregation is bound to know every fellow-member. I beleeve it was not ≈øo in the Church of Jeru≈øalem, or of Samaria. It is incredible, to think that they all knew one another. I ≈øhould bee loath to lay ≈øuch a clog upon your con≈øciences, as to ≈øay,

And this you ought the rather to do, that ≈øo you may contribute to the keeping of the Sacrament of the Lords Supper pure in the Congregation to which you belong. There is much complaint among≈øt many (and not without just cau≈øe) of mixt communions, and of an univer≈øal liberty which ≈øome take in giving the Sacrament promi≈øcuou≈øly
to all that come, though gro≈øly ignorant, and notoriou≈øly ≈øcandalous, and in making (If I may ≈øo ≈øpeak) the Chancel-door, as wide as the Church-door. This in my judgement is a great iniquity.

1 It is to give holy things to Dogs, and to ca≈øt Pearls to Swine. It is a prophanation of the Ordinance, in giving it to tho≈øe who are vi≈øibly unworthy to receive it, and to whom wee know Chri≈øt would not have us to give it.

To prevent this Sacrament-prophanation; there are ≈øome Mini≈øters, who wholly ≈øurcea≈øe from admini≈øtring it. This I allow not, unle≈ø≈øe in ca≈øe of ab≈øolute nece≈øsity. For this is (as it were) to ≈øu≈øpend the whole Congregation, and to deny Children their bread, for fear of giving it to Dogs. The be≈øt way is to follow the advice which our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt gives, Mat. 18, 15, 16, 17. where hee propounds Rules and Directions fort he removing of ≈øcandals out of the Church. If thy Brother ≈øhall tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt thee (≈øaith Chri≈øt) go and tell him his fault between thee and him alone. Hee doth not ≈øay, go, and ≈øeparate pre≈øently (For this is to rend the Church,
not to heal it; This is to hinder thy Brother from Chri≈øt, rather than to gain him to Chri≈øt. Hee doth not ≈øay, God and tell others (for this is to backbite thy Brother. This is to reproach him, rather than to reprove him) But hee ≈øaith, Go and tell him his fault between thee and him alone; if hee ≈øhall hear thee, thou ha≈øt gained thy Brother: But if hee will not hear thee, then take with thee one or two more, &c. And if hee ≈øhall neglect to hear them, tell it to the Church (that is, to ≈øuch who are impowred by Chri≈øt to redre≈øs offences) but if hee neglect to hear the Church, let him, &c. Hence learn,

That all Church-reformation, and Sacrament-purity mu≈øt begin from Church-members, and proceed from them in Chri≈øts way, unto Church-officers: That if any man who is called a Brother, bee a fornicator, or a railer, or a drunkard, or guilty of any other ≈øcandalous ≈øin: It is your duty, who are

But if hee will not hear you, then you are in an orderly way, to bring it to the Church, which if you neglect to do, the ≈øin of Church-pollution is your ≈øin, and not the ≈øin of your Church-officers. If there bee three doors to get into an hou≈øe, hee that keeps mee out of the fir≈øt, keeps mee out of the other two. All Sacramentreformation begins with you, you are the fir≈øt door at which it enters; if you fail of your duty, the ≈øin lyeth at your door, not at ours. It is the cu≈øtome of all people (though otherwi≈øe godly) if a ≈øcandalous ≈øinner bee admitted to the Lords Supper, to charge the ≈øin of it upon the Mini≈øter, and in the mean time to forget that the ≈øin is theirs, not his, becau≈øe they have not done what Chri≈øt would have them, for the gaining of him, and for the inabling of the Church, to proceed

div.p:
THis P≈øalm (out of which my Text is taken) exceeds all the other P≈øalms, not onely in length, but in excellency, ≈øo far (in the judgement of Ambro≈øe) as the light of the Sun excels
the light of the Moon. As the Book of P≈øalms is ≈øtiled by Luther, An Epitome of the Bible, or a little Bible: So may this P≈øalm fitly bee called, An Epitome of the Book of P≈øalms. It was written (as is thought) by David in the dayes of his bani≈øhment under Saul, but ≈øo penned, that the words thereof ≈øuit the condition of all Saints. It is penu doctrinae publicum unicuique apta & convenientia di≈øtribuens, A publick ≈øtore-hou≈øe of heavenly doctrines, di≈øtributing fit, and convenient in≈øtructions to all the people of God, and therefore ≈øhould bee in no le≈øs account with tho≈øe who are ≈øpiritually alive, than is the u≈øe of the Sun, Air, and Fire, with tho≈øe who are naturally alive: It is divided into two and twenty Sections, according to the Hebrew Alphabet and therefore fitly called A holy Alphabet for Sions Schollars. The A, B, C. of godline≈øs, Sixtus Senen≈øis calls it, An Alphabetical Poem. The Jews are ≈øaid to teach it their little
children the fir≈øt thing they learn, and therein they take a very right cour≈øe, both in regard of the heavenly matter, and plain ≈øtile fitted for all capacities. The chief ≈øcope of it, is to ≈øet out the glorious excellencies and perfections of the Law of God. There is not a ver≈øe (except one onely, ≈øay ≈øome learned men in Print, but are therein deceived; but I may truly ≈øay, Ames Couper. Except the 122. and the 90. ver≈øes) in this long P≈øalm, wherein there is not mention made of the Law of God, under the name of Law, or Statutes, or Precepts, or Te≈øtimonies, or Commandements, or Ordinances, or Word, or Promi≈øes, or Wayes, or Judgements, or Name, or Righteou≈øne≈øs, or Truth, &c.

This Text that I have cho≈øen, ≈øets out the great benefit and comfort, which David, found in the Law of God in the time of his affliction‚ÄîIt kept him from peri≈øhing. Had not thy Law been my delights, I had peri≈øhed in my affliction.

The word Law is taken diver≈øly in Scripture, ≈øometimes for the Moral Law, James 2.10. Sometimes for the whole Oeconomy, Polity, and Regiment of Mo≈øes, for the whole Mo≈øaical di≈øpen≈øation by Laws, partly moral, partly Judicial, partly Ceremonial, Gal. 3.23. Sometimes for the five Books of Mo≈øes, Luke 24. 44. Sometimes for the whole Doctrine of God contained in the Scriptures of the Old Te≈øtament, John 7. 49. By Law in this place is meant, all tho≈øe Books of the Scripture which were written when this P≈øalm was penned. But I ≈øhall handle it in a larger ≈øen≈øe, as it comprehends all the Books both of the Old and New Te≈øtament. For the word Law is ≈øometimes al≈øo taken for the Go≈øpel, as it is Micah 4.2. I≈øa. 2.3. The meaning then is, Unle≈øs thy Law, that is, Thy Word, had been my delights, I ≈øhould have peri≈øhed in mine affliction.

David ≈øpeaks this (≈øaith Mu≈øculus) of the di≈øtre≈ø≈øed condition hee was
in when per≈øecuted by Saul, forced to flye to the Phili≈øtins, and ≈øometimes to hide him≈øelf in the rocks and caves of the earth. Hic vero ≈øimile e≈øt, fui≈ø≈øe illi ad manum codicem divinae legis, &c. It is very likely (≈øaith hee) that hee had the Book of Gods Law with him, by the reading of which, hee mitigated and allayed his ≈øorrows, and kept him≈øelf pure from communicating with the Heathen in their ≈øuper≈øtitions. The Greek Scholia≈øts ≈øay, That David uttered the≈øe words, A Saule pul≈øus, & apud Phili≈øtaeos & impios homines agere coactus, when driven from Saul, and compelled to live amon≈øt the wicked Phili≈øtins, &c. for hee would have been allured to have communicated with them in their impieties, had hee not carried about him the meditation of the word of God. Unle≈øs thy Law had been my delights, &c.

2 Let us labour that the good wee reap by our afflictions, may abide upon us after The good wee get by our Afflictions mu≈øt remain with us after our recovery. our recovery from them. to the vomit, &c. Such was Pharoah, whil≈øt hee was plagued he confe≈ø≈øed his ≈øin, and prayed for pardon, but as ≈øoon as ever the judgement was gone, hee hardened his heart. Such were the I≈øraelites, P≈øalm 78.34, 35, 36, 37. They were not ≈øtedfa≈øt, they turned back. Ju≈øt like a truantly School-boy, who while his Ma≈øter is whipping him, will promi≈øe any thing, but when it is done, forgets pre≈øently to do what hee promi≈øed: Or like unto water, which while it is upon the fire is very hot, but as ≈øoon as ever it is taken off the fire, pre≈øently groweth cold. I knew a man who in the time of his ≈øickne≈øs, was ≈øo terrified in his con≈øcience for his ≈øins, that hee made the very bed to ≈øhake, upon which hee lay, and cried out all night long, I am damned, I am damned, and made many and great Prote≈øtations of amendment of life, if God would bee plea≈øed to recover him. In a little while hee did recover, and being recovered, was as bad, and as wicked as ever before.

And therefore let us labour that the good wee get by our afflictions, may not vani≈øh away with our afflictions, but may abide on us after wee are recovered, that wee may bee able to ≈øay with David, It is good for mee that I was afflicted, not onely that I am, but that I was. David prai≈øeth God in health, for the good hee had got in ≈øickne≈øs, and which ≈øtill abode with him. Let us ≈øay with the ≈øame Prophet, P≈øal. 66.13, 14. I will go into thy hou≈øe with burnt offerings, I will pay thee my vows which my lips have uttered, and my mouth hath ≈øpoken, when I was in trouble. Let us pray unto God that his afflictions may not onely skin over our ≈øpiritual di≈øea≈øes, and coup up our ≈øins; but mortifie them, and ≈øo change our natures, that wee may never return to folly.

I will conclude this point with a famous ≈øaying of Plinius Secundus, worthy to bee written in letters of gold. A friend writes to him, and
intreats him to give him advice how to frame his life, ≈øo as hee might live as becomes a good man. Hee returns him this an≈øwer: I will not pre≈øcribe many rules, there is this one onely which I commend to thee above all other. Ut tales e≈ø≈øe per≈øeveremus ≈øani, quales nos futuros profitemur infirmi. Let us labour to continue and per≈øevere to bee ≈øuch, when wee are well; as wee purpo≈øe, and promi≈øe to our ≈øelves to bee, when wee are ≈øick. There is hardly any man ≈øo wicked, but hee will in ≈øickne≈øs make many and great promi≈øes of a new life, and of univer≈øal reformation if God would re≈øtore him. Now then if wee not onely bee ≈øuch, but continue to bee ≈øuch when re≈øtored, as wee promi≈øe to be when ≈øick, then wee ≈øhall bee excellent Schollars, in the School of Affliction, and God will either (as I have already ≈øaid) deliver us out of affliction, or ≈øend us to heaven by affliction. So much for the fir≈øt Truth ≈øuppo≈øed.

div.head: THE Word of God is the Saints Delights.
SERMON II.

epigraph.q: Unle≈øs thy Law had been my delights, I ≈øhould then have peri≈øhed in mine Afflictions.

div.p: NOw I come to ≈øpeak of the ≈øecond truth ≈øuppo≈øed in the Text.

That the Word of God is the Saints darling and
delights; not only their delight, but in the plural number, their delights, that is (as our Annotations ≈øay) a Saint doth greatly delight in Gods Law, or as Junius. All the delight of a Saint is in Gods Law; Gods word is the center of his delights; Ni≈øi lex tua erat omnis oblectatio mea: Many were the troubles and ≈øorrows of Davids life, but again≈øt them all hee found as many comforts and delectations in Gods Word; therefore he ≈øaith, ver≈ø. 29. Thy Te≈øtimonies are my delights, &c. and 143. Trouble and angui≈øh have taken hold on mee, yet thy Commandements are my delights; And in the Text, unle≈øs thy Law had been my delights, &c. Whil≈øt others delight in vanity and iniquity, whil≈øt others take plea≈øure in hunting, hawking, carding, dicing, eating, and drinking, the Saints of God, can Rea≈øons why the Saints take ≈øo much delight in Gods Law. ≈øay with Au≈øtin, Sacrae Scripturae tuae ≈øunt ≈øanctae deliciae meae, Thy holy Scriptures are my holy delights.

Que≈øt. Why do the Saints of God tale
≈øuch delight in the Law of God?

An≈øw. 1 Becau≈øe they are ≈øpiritually illightened; their eyes are opened to behold the glory, and beauty, and to under≈øtand the deep my≈øteries of the Law; therefore David prayeth, ver≈ø. 18. Open thou mine eyes, that I may behold wondrous things out of thy Law, As the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith of the Jews, 2 Cor. 3. 14, 15, 16. That to this day there is a vail over their hearts, when Mo≈øes is read, and when they ≈øhall turn to the Lord, this vail ≈øhall bee removed: So it is with Chri≈øtians, when a wicked man reads the word, there is a vail over his eyes, and over his heart, and over the Scriptures, The God of this world hath ≈øo blinded his eyes, that hee cannot behold the beauty and glory of them; but the True Saint hath this vail removed, Chri≈øt hath anointed his eyes with his ≈øpiritual eye-≈øalve; hee ≈øeeth a ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing excellency in the Word of God, and therefore cannot but delight in it.

2 Becau≈øe they are not only illightened, but regenerated; And as children new born, by the in≈øtinct of nature, have a natural appetite to milk for con≈øervation of their life; ≈øo the new born Saint, by the in≈øtinct of grace, hath a ≈øpiritual appetite to the Word of God, according to that of Saint Peter, 1 Pet. 2. 2. As new born babes de≈øire the ≈øincere Milk of the Word, that you may grow thereby: The Word of God is the Saints food, and as it is impo≈ø≈øible for a child unborn to de≈øire food, ≈øo for a man unregenerated to hunger after, and take true plea≈øure in the Word; and as it is impo≈ø≈øible for a new born child, not to delight in Milk, ≈øo it is as impo≈ø≈øible for a regenerate Chri≈øtian, not to delight in the Law of God.

3 Becau≈øe a true Saint hath the Law of God written in his heart, according to that precious promi≈øe of the Covenant of grace, Jer. 31. 33. I will put my Law in their inward parts, and
write it in their hearts. A Saints heart is the counterpane to Gods Law. The Law is within his heart, P≈øal. 40.8. and as it is in the Hebrew, in the mid≈øt of his bowels, in medio vt≈øcerum. God hath infu≈øed a principle of grace into his inward parts, whereby hee is not onely inclined, but inabled to walk in all the Commandements of the Law blamele≈øs. A true Saint hides the Law in his heart, as a choice Jewel in a mo≈øt precious Cabinet, as David ≈øaith ver≈øe 9. I have hid thy Law in my heart. Hid it as a rare trea≈øure. So doth every Saint, and therefore cannot but delight in it.

4 Becau≈øe the ≈øame holy Spirit that wrote the word, dwelleth in every true Saint. It is certain that all Scripture is of Divine In≈øpiration, and that the holy men of God ≈øpake, as they were guided by the Holy Gho≈øt. And it is as certain, That the ≈øame Holy Gho≈øt dwelleth in every Saint, Rom. 8. 11. And by vertue of the in-dwelling of
the Spirit, they are ≈øweetly and powerfully drawn to make the Law of God their chiefe≈øt delight.

5 Becau≈øe it is Gods inditement and invention. This rea≈øon is brought in the Text, Unle≈øs thy Law, &c. It is the Law of that God in whom they delight. It tran≈øcribes the minde and heart of God. A true Saint ≈øeeth the Name, Authority, Power, Wi≈ødome, and Goodne≈øs of God in every letter of it, and therefore cannot but take plea≈øure in it. It is an Epi≈øtle ≈øent down to him from the God of heaven. It is one of the greate≈øt Lovetokens that ever God gave to his Church. There are two great gifts that God hath given to his people. The Word Chri≈øt, and the Word of Chri≈øt. Both are un≈øpeakably great. But the fir≈øt will do us no good without the ≈øecond.

6 A true Saint cannot but delight in the word of God, becau≈øe it is his Inheritance, ver≈ø. 111. Thy te≈øtimonies
have I taken as an heritage for ever, for they are the rejoycing of my heart. Therefore they were the rejoycing of his heart, becau≈øe they were his everla≈øting Inheritance.

7 Becau≈øe hee findes a ≈øweetne≈øs in it. Delight is nothing el≈øe but a pa≈ø≈øion of the ≈øoul, ari≈øing from the ≈øweetne≈øs of the object that we enjoy. Things that are good, pre≈øent, ≈øuitable, and ≈øweet, are the object of our delights, ≈øuch is the word of God to every true Saint. It is ≈øweeter than the hony, and the hony-comb, P≈øal. 19. 10. So al≈øo P≈øal. 119.103. How ≈øweet are thy words unto my ta≈øte, yea ≈øweeter than hony to my mouth. A Saint mu≈øt needs delight in it, it is ≈øo ≈øuitable, and ≈øo ≈øweet.

8 Becau≈øe hee loves the Law. Now that which wee love, wee cannot but delight in, when wee come to enjoy it. A true Saint doth not onely love the Law, but hee loves it exceedingly, P≈øal. 119.167. My ≈øoul hath kept thy
te≈øtimonies, and I love them exceedingly. A true Saint can ≈øay with David, P≈øal, 119.97. Oh how do I love thy Law! and ver≈ø. 127. I love they Commandements above gold, yea above fine gold; and ver≈ø. 72. The Law of thy mouth is better to mee than thou≈øands of gold and ≈øilver. Now becau≈øe the Saints of God are ≈øo inamoured with the Law of God, therefore it is that they cannot but delight in it, as David ≈øaith, P≈øal. 119.47. I will delight my ≈øelf in thy Commandements, which I have loved. Hee that loves the Commandements (as all Saints do) cannot but delight in them.

U≈øe. This ≈øhews that there are but few true Saints among≈øt us. There are many bastard Saints, and nominal Saints, but few true and real Saints. Wee live in an age, wherein there were never more Saints, and never fewer, never more by outward Profe≈øsion, and never fewer by a holy Conver≈øation. It is the property of a true Saint to
make the word of God his darling and delights.

But where ≈øhall wee finde ≈øuch Saints? It is ea≈øie to finde out men that can ≈øay, Eating and drinking is my delight, carding and dicing is my delight, reading of vain and trifling books is my delight; to ≈øatisfie the lu≈øts of the fle≈øh is my delight. But where is the man that can truly ≈øay as David doth? The Law of God is my delights, and the joy and rejoycing of my heart for ever. Au≈øtin profe≈ø≈øeth of him≈øelf, that before his conver≈øion, hee took no plea≈øure in the word of God. His proud heart (as hee ≈øaith) would not ≈øtoop to the humble expre≈ø≈øions of it. After his conver≈øion, hee was ravi≈øhed with the beauty and excellency of the Scriptures, but before his conver≈øion, hee ≈øaw no excellency in them. Policarp (though a great Schollar, yet a notorious Athei≈øt) profe≈ø≈øeth mo≈øt bla≈øphemou≈øly, that hee never lo≈øt more time than in reading the
Scripture. And it is reported of Plato, that when hee had read the fir≈øt Chapter of Gene≈øis, hee ≈øaid, Hic vir multa dicit, ≈øed nihil probat. This man ≈øaith many things, but proveth nothing. Where ≈øhall wee finde the man that puts a due e≈øtimation upon the word of God? That prizeth it above gold, yea above much fine gold? That rejoyeeth in thy word as much as in all riches, ver≈ø. 14. That can appeal to God, and ≈øay as David, ver≈ø. 159. Con≈øider, Oh Lord, how I love thy Precepts? and ver≈øe 97. Oh how do I love thy Law? There are ≈øome men that can delight in any thing but in God, and his Word, and his Ordinances; They can delight in the creatures of God, but cannot delight in the Ordinances of God. They can delight in the gifts of God, in riches, and health, and honours: But they cannot delight in the God of the≈øe gifts. They can delight in books of Philo≈øophy, and humanity, but they cannot delight in the word of God.
Mark the ≈øad condition that the≈øe are in.

It is a certain ≈øign that there is a vail over their eyes and hearts, that they are not yet anointed with Chri≈øts eye-≈øalve; that the God of the world hath blinded their eyes that they cannot ≈øee the glorious excellencies of the Law of God.
It is certain that they are not born anew, for if they were new born babes, they would de≈øire the ≈øincere milk of the word.

It is certain that the Law of God is not yet written in their hearts, and that the Spirit of God doth not dwell in them. It is certain that they have no part, nor portion in the word of God, that they never ta≈øted the ≈øweetne≈øs that is in it, and that they have no true love to God, nor to his word. It is a true ≈øaying, Qui regem amat, legem amat, hee that loves a King, will love his Law. And I may ≈øay, Qui Deum amat, legem Dei amat: Hee
that loves God, will love the Law of God, which is nothing el≈øe but his Image, and his Picture, his la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament, his ble≈ø≈øed love-token. And therefore if you delight not in the Law of God, it is evident you do not delight in the God of this Law. And if you delight not in God, hee will not delight in you; unle≈øs it bee to laugh at your de≈øtruction, as it is Prov. 1.26.
Q. But how ≈øhall I know whether I do delight in the word of God, or no?
An≈øw. You ≈øhall know it by the≈øe notes.

1 Hee that delights in Gods Law, will bee very frequent in meditating and reading of it, and very often in ≈øpeaking of it. Thus ≈øaith David, P≈øal. 1.2. His delight is in the Law of the Lord, and therein hee will meditate day and night. And P≈øalm 119.97. Oh how do I love thy Law, it is my meditation all the day. So al≈øo ver≈ø. 15, 16. 23. Hee that takes plea≈øure in the
Law, hee will bee often thinking of it, as Chri≈øt ≈øaith, Matth. 6.21. Where the trea≈øure is, there the heart will bee al≈øo: If the word of God bee thy trea≈øure, thou wilt meditate on it, Cogitatione crebr√¢, long√¢, & profund√¢. Thou wilt frequently think of it, and when thou beginne≈øt to think of it, thou wilt dwell upon the thought of it, as a Bee dwels (as it were) upon the flower to ≈øuck out the ≈øweetne≈øs that is in it, and thou wilt think of it with deep and ≈øerious meditations, and contemplations, thou wilt dive into the un≈øearchable riches and trea≈øures that are in the Word. And as thou wilt meditate on it, ≈øo thou wilt bee often, and unweari≈øome in reading and peru≈øing of it, and di≈øcour≈øing about it. A man that delights in hunting, is never weary of talking of hunting, and he that delights in the world, of ≈øpeaking about the world; and if you did delight in Gods word, you would be very frequent, and indefatigable in di≈øcour≈øing of it.

2 If you did delight in the Word of God, you would delight in the Mini≈øters and Amba≈ø≈øadors of the Word lawfully commi≈ø≈øionated by Chri≈øt: For the great work of the Mini≈øtry is to expound and apply the Word; and therefore if you di≈ø-re≈øpect the godly learned lawful Mini≈øtry of the Word, you take no delight in the Word.

3 They that delight in the Word, will bee at any co≈øt to bring the Word to their congregations, they will part with thou≈øands of gold and ≈øilver, rather than with the Word; Hee that e≈øteems the VVord above thou≈øands, will bee willing to part with hundreds for the Words ≈øake. Hee will account a famine of the Word more bitter than a famine of bread; by how much the ≈øoul is better than the body, by ≈øo much will hee bee more troubled for a ≈øoul-famine, than a bodily.

4 Hee that delights truely in the Law, will ≈øincerely labour to obey it, and bee much grieved when it is di≈øobeyed.
1 Hee will ≈øincerely labour to obey it, hee will make the Word of God the man of his coun≈øel, ver≈ø. 24. And therefore you that delight in ≈øin, you cannot bee ≈øaid to delight in the Word; and you that are not pained and grieved when others ≈øin, you are
not among≈øt the number of tho≈øe that take plea≈øure in Gods Law, or in whom God takes plea≈øure.

U≈øe 2 Let us make it appear that wee are Saints indeed and in truth, not only Saints in Mans, but in Gods Calender, by following the example of holy David, ≈øet down in the Text. Let us make the Law of God our joyes, and our delights. Let mee ≈øpeak to you in the words of the Apo≈øtle, Col. 3. 16. Let the VVord of God dwell richly in you, &c. not only with you, but in you, And in the Words of Chri≈øt, John 5. 39. Search the Scriptures, for therein you hope to finde eternal life. E≈øteem the VVord of God above our nece≈ø≈øary food. Let us love it above gold, yea, above fine gold; let it bee dearer to us than thou≈øands of gold and ≈øilver, ≈øweeter than the hony,
and the hony-comb.

You that are Gentlemen, remember what Hierom reports of Nepotianus, a young Gentleman of Rome, qui long √¢ & a≈øsidu√¢ meditatione ≈øcripturarum, pectus ≈øuum fecerat bibliothecam Chri≈øti, who by often and a≈ø≈øiduous meditation of the Scriptures, made his brea≈øt the library of Chri≈øt. You that are Schollars, remember Cranmor and Ridley; the former, learnt the New Te≈øtament by heart in his journey to Rome, the latter in Pembrook-hall walks in Cambridge. And what is ≈øaid of Beza, that when hee was above four≈øcore years old, hee could ≈øay perfectly by heart any Greek Chapter
in Pauls Epi≈øtles.

Let all men con≈øider that hyperbollical ≈øpeech of Luther, That hee would not live in Paradi≈øe without the VVord and with it hee could live well enough in Hell. This ≈øpeech of Luthers mu≈øt bee under≈øtood cum grano ≈øalis.

Qu. May not a wicked man delight in the VVord of God? is it not ≈øaid of Herod, Mark. 6. 20. that hee heard John Bapti≈øt gladly, and of the ≈øtony ground, Luk. 8. 13. that it received the Word with joy? Is it not ≈øaid of the I≈øraelites remaining wicked, that they delighted to know Gods waies, and took delight in approaching to God, I≈øa. 58. 2. and of the Jews, Joh. 5. 35. that they were willing for a ≈øea≈øon to rejoyce in the Light; held forth by the preaching of John Bapti≈øt.
An≈øw. There is a wide and va≈øt difference between the joy and delight which a true Saint takes in Gods Word, and that which may bee found in an hypocrite.

1 The delight of a godly man, is orderly and ≈øea≈øonable. It is the con≈øequent of conviction and humiliation; For though Joy bee the great work of the Spirit, yet it is not the fir≈øt work. Fir≈øt, The Spirit by the Word convinceth and humbleth, and then comforteth; therefore Chri≈øt ≈øaith, Mat. 5. 4. Ble≈øsed are tho≈øe that mourn, for they ≈øhall bee comforted; and David ≈øaith, P≈øal. 126. 5. They that ≈øow in tears, ≈øhall reap in joy. But the joy of an hypocrite is un≈øea≈øonable and di≈øorderly. It is his fir≈øt work. It is ≈øaid of the ≈øtony ground, that when they heard the Word, they received it immediately with gladne≈ø≈øe, Mark. 4. 16. It is not ≈øaid, they received it fir≈øt with ≈øorrow, and then with gladne≈ø≈øe. Here is mention of joy without any antecedent humiliation.
Nay, the Text ≈øaith expre≈øly, Luk. 8. 6. it lacked moi≈øture, and therefore it withered away. There are many Profe≈ø≈øors in our daies that skip from ≈øin, to joy at fir≈øt, that all in an in≈øtant are in the highe≈øt form of ≈øin, and in the highe≈øt form of comfort, that skip out of the lap of the Devil, into the lap of joy: The≈øe are as the ≈øtony ground. The≈øe are wanton Chri≈øtians: They ≈øow before they plough; they know not the bitterne≈ø≈øe of ≈øin, and therefore in time of temptation fall away.

2 The delight that a godly man takes in the Word, is a well-rooted delight. It is rooted in an humble, good, and honest heart, as is ≈øaid of the good ground, Luk. 8. 15. But the delight of an hypocrite is ≈øhallow and ≈øuperficial; as his graces are ≈øleight and formal, ≈øo are his delights. Therefore it is ≈øaid of the ≈øeed that fell upon the ≈øtony ground, that it had no root, Luk. 8. 13. and Matth. 13. 5. it wanted depth of
earth, and therefore when the Sun aro≈øe, it was ≈øcorched. The Apo≈øtle hints this, Heb. 6. 4.‚Äîand have ta≈øted the good Word of God. The delight of a wicked man in the Word, is but a ta≈øting and ≈øipping, no ≈øoaking; a floating aloft in the river of Chri≈øts blood, no diving down to the bottom. A man may ta≈øte a thing, and not like it, ta≈øte, and like it, and yet not come up to the price of it, as the young man, Matth. 19. 22. Hee was very de≈øirous to injoy eternal life, but hee would not part with his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions for the obtaining of it. A Cook ta≈øteth of the meat hee dre≈ø≈øeth, but they only that are invited eate of it.

Ta≈øting doth not imply habitual grace. A man may ta≈øte that which hee never dige≈øteth, nor concocteth. The I≈øraelites ta≈øted of the fir≈øt fruits of the Land of Canaan, and yet did not enter into Canaan. Such is the joy of the hypocrite. It is outward and ≈øuperficial: But the delight of a true
Saint is inward, ≈øolid, and ≈øub≈øtantial. Jeremy ≈øaith, that the Word of God was the joy and rejoycing of his heart, and that hee did eat it, Jer. 15. 16. hee did not only ta≈øte it, but eate it. And Paul ≈øaith, Rom. 7. 22. I delight in the Law of God after the inward man; His delights had depth of earth, they were well dige≈øted, and concocted.

3 It is ≈øuperlative and overtopping. A godly man delighteth more in God, and his Word, than in any worldly thing what≈øoever. Lord lift thou up (≈øaith David, P≈øal. 4. 6, 7.) The light of thy countenance upon us, thou ha≈øt put gladne≈øs in my heart, more than in the time that their corn and their wine encrea≈øed. So al≈øo, P≈øal. 43. 4.‚Äîunto God my exceeding Joy, P≈øa. 137.6. If I prefer not Jeru≈øalem above my chief Joy. And P≈øal. 119.72.127. The delight of a Saint in Gods Word overtoppeth all his creature delights, and injoyments, and for the joy he findes in it, he will fell all hee hath to purcha≈øe it, Matth. 13. 44.

div.head: Rule 13.
div.p:
Study thy intere≈øt in the promi≈øes in the time of health, and outward The 13. Rule for the right Application of the Promi≈øes, pro≈øperity; For I find by experience that a childe of God (under outward affliction, or divine de≈øertion, or extream melancholy) is many times like a man in the dark. A man in the dark cannot (though never ≈øo learned) read in a book of the cleare≈øt print, or faire≈øt character, hee cannot (though never ≈øo active) undertake any thing of weight. No more can a childe of God in the hour of di≈øtre≈øs; read his evidences for heaven, much le≈øs ≈øtudy to finde out evidences; hee looks upon all the promi≈øes with a black pair of ≈øpectacles, and wants light to ≈øee his intere≈øt in them. When Sion was
in di≈øtre≈øs, ≈øhee ≈øaid, God had for≈øaken I≈øa. 49. 14. P≈øal. 116. 11. her, and her Lord had forgotten her. P≈øal 88. 3. 14, 15, 16, 17, 18. ≈øaid in his ha≈øte hee was cut off from before Gods eyes, Thus did Heman. Chri≈øt him≈øelf cried out, when hee was upon the Cro≈øs, with a loud voyce, My God, my God, why ha≈øt thou for≈øaken mee? So a di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Chri≈øtian, (when under extream melancholy, divine de≈øertion, or ≈øome great affliction) is no fit judge at ≈øuch a time of his intere≈øt in the promi≈øes. And afterward when ≈øhee was in great di≈øtre≈øs, and ready to bee burn't as a Harlot, ≈øhee then brought her ≈øtaffe, and ≈øignet, and bracelets, and ≈øaid, By the man who≈øe the≈øe are, am I with childe, and thereby ≈øhee ≈øaved her life. In time of health ≈øtudy thy intere≈øt in the promi≈øes, and in time of ≈øickne≈øs live upon what thou ha≈øt ≈øtudied, then bring forth thy ≈øtaffe and bracelets, &c. then produce thy evidences, and make u≈øe of them as ≈øpiritual buttere≈ø≈øes to keep thee from falling into de≈øpair. Mrs. Diggons dwelling with Mr. Moor in Aldermanbury. I knew a very godly woman (not unknown to many here) who in her life time had taken a great deal or pain to compo≈øe, and write down her evidences

Thus I have in three Sermons taught you how to make u≈øe of Scripture-promi≈øes, as conduits of ≈øoul-≈øupportation, and ≈øoul-con≈øolation, in the day of di≈øtre≈øs. When you hereafter read the Bible, remember the promi≈øing-word, (as well as the commanding and threatning word) make a Catalogue of the promi≈øes, meditate upon the pretiou≈øne≈øs, freene≈øs, u≈øefulne≈øs, latitude, richne≈øs, and immutability of them. For this purpo≈øe, ≈øtudy the≈øe thirteen Rules and Directions. Pray unto God to give thee ≈øpiritual eyes, to ≈øee thy intere≈øt in them, and ≈øpiritual hands to reach out after them. There is one Objection behinde, which when I have an≈øwered, I have done. For a di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Chri≈øtian will object, and ≈øay,

Object. Though the promi≈øes are rare cordials, and ≈øhall all of them bee certainly fulfilled, yet God is oftentimes long before hee fulfills them, and while God is fulfilling of his promi≈øes, I may in the mean time peri≈øh in my affliction.

But yet notwith≈øtanding all this, you mu≈øt know, That though the way of God, in performing his promi≈øes, bee very mysterious and ≈øecret, yet hee will at la≈øt perform every „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and tittle of them. 1 It is our duty to wait patiently, and beleevingly, till Providences and Three duties to bee practi≈øed when providences run cro≈øs to promi≈øes. I≈øa. 28.16. Promi≈øes meet together. hee prayed, Dan. 9. 2. 3. Thus did David, P≈øal. 56.9, 10.57. 1, 2. Thus mu≈øt you do. div.head: A Brief Repetition of what was ≈øaid of Mris. Elizabeth Moore at her Burial.
div.p: THough I have fini≈øhed my Text, yet I have another Text remaining, of which I mu≈øt ≈øpeak a few words, and that is, The party decea≈øed, at who≈øe funeral wee are here met.
